<ce:figure id="sch1">
<ce:label>Scheme 1</ce:label>
<ce:caption>
<ce:simple-para view="all">Important chain-like structural types of isonicotinic acid bridging LN centers: (a) 1-1-1; (b) 2-1-2; (c) 2-2-2; and (d) 2-4-2 types, in which the number indicates the number of the bridges.</ce:simple-para>
</ce:caption>
<ce:link locator="sc1"></ce:link>
</ce:figure>
elements.clean_text: Scheme 1  Important chain-like structural types of isonicotinic acid bridging LN centers: (a) 1-1-1; (b) 2-1-2; (c) 2-2-2; and (d) 2-4-2 types, in which the number indicates the number of the bridges.

elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel bimetallic 4f-3d metal-isonicotinic acid inorganic-organic hybrid complex [Sm(C6NO2H5)3(H2O)2]2  n ⋅(H5O2) n (ZnCl5) n (ZnCl4)2  n ⋅(H2O)2  n  (1) has been synthesized via hydrothermal reaction and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 is characteristic of a one-dimensional polycationic chain-like structure and unprecedented ZnCl5 3- species. Photoluminescent investigation reveals that the title complex displays interesting emissions in a wide region. Optical absorption spectra of 1 reveal the presence of an optical gap of 3.59eV.

It is characteristic of a one-dimensional polycationic chain-like structure. Photoluminescent investigation reveals that the title complex displays interesting emissions in a wide region. Optical absorption spectra of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> reveal the presence of a wide optical bandgap.</ce:simple-para>

Graphical abstract

A novel bimetallic 4f-3d metal-isonicotinic acid inorganic-organic hybrid complex was synthesized. It is characteristic of a one-dimensional polycationic chain-like structure. Photoluminescent investigation reveals that the title complex displays interesting emissions in a wide region. Optical absorption spectra of 1 reveal the presence of a wide optical bandgap.

<ce:section-title>Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In recent years, the research of the trivalent lanthanide ions complexes continues to be an active research area, which may be ascribed to the remarkable physical properties of these complexes and their potential applications as magnetic functional materials, electroluminescent devices, catalysis, zeolite-like materials, and luminescent probes or labels in biological systems . There is also an aesthetic perspective for the vast amount of inorganic–organic hybrid materials, the intriguing variety of the architectures and topologies that can be obtained by self-assembling metal ions, and multifunctional ligands attract chemists. So far, although the synthesis of inorganic–organic hybrid materials based on transition metals has become widespread , there are relatively few reports on lanthanide-based inorganic–organic hybrid materials despite their potential applications in luminescence and other fields . To our knowledge, lanthanide-based inorganic–organic hybrid materials with aromatic carboxylic acids exhibit good thermal and luminescent stability for practical application. Besides, transition metal complexes containing group 12 (IIB) elements are particularly attractive for many reasons, such as, the variety of coordination numbers and geometries provided by the <ce:italic>d</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">10</ce:sup> configuration of the IIB metal ions, the well-known toxicity of cadmium and mercury, semiconductive properties, and the essential role in biological systems of zinc, and so forth. Furthermore, the isonicotinate anion is a quite interesting tecton in constructing extended structures because it is an asymmetrical divergent ligand with a nitrogen atom at one end and two oxygen atoms from the carboxylato group at the other end. The isonicotinate anion can link two metal centers by coordinating a metal center with the nitrogen atom and, to the other end, with one or two carboxylato oxygen atoms . We believe that LN–IIB-based (LN=lanthanide) inorganic–organic hybrid materials with aromatic carboxylic acids as ligands may have novel structural topologies and properties, such as luminescence, semiconductivity, magnetism, electro- and photochemistry, catalysis, thermochromism and so on. Therefore, we recently became interested in the crystal engineering of LN–IIB-based inorganic–organic hybrid materials with isonicotinic acid as ligand. In this paper, we reported the synthesis, crystal structure, and semiconductive and luminescent properties of [Sm(C<ce:inf loc="post">6</ce:inf>NO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>]<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>

elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In recent years, the research of the trivalent lanthanide ions complexes continues to be an active research area, which may be ascribed to the remarkable physical properties of these complexes and their potential applications as magnetic functional materials, electroluminescent devices, catalysis, zeolite-like materials, and luminescent probes or labels in biological systems . There is also an aesthetic perspective for the vast amount of inorganic-organic hybrid materials, the intriguing variety of the architectures and topologies that can be obtained by self-assembling metal ions, and multifunctional ligands attract chemists. So far, although the synthesis of inorganic-organic hybrid materials based on transition metals has become widespread , there are relatively few reports on lanthanide-based inorganic-organic hybrid materials despite their potential applications in luminescence and other fields . To our knowledge, lanthanide-based inorganic-organic hybrid materials with aromatic carboxylic acids exhibit good thermal and luminescent stability for practical application. Besides, transition metal complexes containing group 12 (IIB) elements are particularly attractive for many reasons, such as, the variety of coordination numbers and geometries provided by the d 10 configuration of the IIB metal ions, the well-known toxicity of cadmium and mercury, semiconductive properties, and the essential role in biological systems of zinc, and so forth. Furthermore, the isonicotinate anion is a quite interesting tecton in constructing extended structures because it is an asymmetrical divergent ligand with a nitrogen atom at one end and two oxygen atoms from the carboxylato group at the other end. The isonicotinate anion can link two metal centers by coordinating a metal center with the nitrogen atom and, to the other end, with one or two carboxylato oxygen atoms . We believe that LN-IIB-based (LN=lanthanide) inorganic-organic hybrid materials with aromatic carboxylic acids as ligands may have novel structural topologies and properties, such as luminescence, semiconductivity, magnetism, electro- and photochemistry, catalysis, thermochromism and so on. Therefore, we recently became interested in the crystal engineering of LN-IIB-based inorganic-organic hybrid materials with isonicotinic acid as ligand. In this paper, we reported the synthesis, crystal structure, and semiconductive and luminescent properties of [Sm(C6NO2H5)3(H2O)2]2  n ⋅(H5O2) n (ZnCl5) n (ZnCl4)2  n ⋅(H2O)2  n  (1), which contains a novel one-dimensional polycationic chain and unprecedented ZnCl5 3- anions.

elements.content: <ce:section-title>Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title>Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">All reactants of A.R. grade were obtained commercially and used without further purification. Fluorescence excitation and emission spectra of solid-state sample were collected on a computer-controlled JY FluoroMax-3 spectrometer with high resolution (excitation slit width, 3<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm; emission slit width, 5<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm) at room temperature. The UV–vis spectra were recorded at room temperature on a computer-controlled PE Lambda 900 UV–vis spectrometer equipped with an integrating sphere in the wavelength range of 190–1100<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm. BaSO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> plate was used as a reference (100% reflectance), on which the finely ground powder of the samples were coated. The absorption spectra were calculated from reflection spectra by the Kubelka–Munk function : <ce:italic>α</ce:italic>/<ce:italic>S</ce:italic>=(1−<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>)<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>/2<ce:italic>R</ce:italic>, <ce:italic>α</ce:italic> is the absorption coefficient, <ce:italic>S</ce:italic> is the scattering coefficient which is practically wavelength independent when the particle size is larger than 5<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>μm, and <ce:italic>R</ce:italic> is the reflectance.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

All reactants of A.R. grade were obtained commercially and used without further purification. Fluorescence excitation and emission spectra of solid-state sample were collected on a computer-controlled JY FluoroMax-3 spectrometer with high resolution (excitation slit width, 3nm; emission slit width, 5nm) at room temperature. The UV-vis spectra were recorded at room temperature on a computer-controlled PE Lambda 900 UV-vis spectrometer equipped with an integrating sphere in the wavelength range of 190-1100nm. BaSO4 plate was used as a reference (100% reflectance), on which the finely ground powder of the samples were coated. The absorption spectra were calculated from reflection spectra by the Kubelka-Munk function : α/S=(1-R)2/2R, α is the absorption coefficient, S is the scattering coefficient which is practically wavelength independent when the particle size is larger than 5μm, and R is the reflectance.

elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Sm(C6NO2H5)3(H2O)2]2  n ⋅(H5O2) n (ZnCl5) n (ZnCl4)2  n ⋅(H2O)2  n    (  1  )   

The title complex was prepared by mixing SmCl3⋅6H2O (1mmol, 0.365g), ZnCl2 (1mmol, 0.136g), isonicotinic acid (1mmol, 0.123g), and 10mL distilled water in a 25mL teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 180°C for 7 days. After being slowly cooled to room temperature at 6°C/h, colorless crystals suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained. The yield was 76% (based on samarium).

<ce:section-title>Crystal structure determination</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">X-ray diffraction data were collected on Rigaku Mercury CCD X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo-<ce:italic>K</ce:italic>α radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>=0.71073<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å) using a <ce:italic>ω</ce:italic> scan technique. CrystalClear software was used for data reduction and empirical absorption correction. The structure was solved by the direct methods using the Siemens SHELXTL<ce:sup loc="post">TM</ce:sup> Version 5 package of crystallographic software. The difference Fourier maps based on the atomic positions yield all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atom positions were generated theoretically, except for those on the lattice water molecules that is yielded by the difference Fourier maps, allowed to ride on their respective parent atoms and included in the structure factor calculations with assigned isotropic thermal parameters but were not refined. The structure was refined using a full-matrix least-squares refinement on <ce:italic>F</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The summary of crystallographic data and structure analysis is given in

elements.clean_text:
Crystal structure determination

X-ray diffraction data were collected on Rigaku Mercury CCD X-ray diffractometer with graphite monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ=0.71073Å) using a ω scan technique. CrystalClear software was used for data reduction and empirical absorption correction. The structure was solved by the direct methods using the Siemens SHELXTLTM Version 5 package of crystallographic software. The difference Fourier maps based on the atomic positions yield all non-hydrogen atoms. The hydrogen atom positions were generated theoretically, except for those on the lattice water molecules that is yielded by the difference Fourier maps, allowed to ride on their respective parent atoms and included in the structure factor calculations with assigned isotropic thermal parameters but were not refined. The structure was refined using a full-matrix least-squares refinement on F 2. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. The summary of crystallographic data and structure analysis is given in  . The selected bond lengths and bond angles are listed in  .

<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>-isonicotinic acid ligands in a 2-4-2 (the number indicates the number of the bridges) mode to construct a one-dimensional polycationic chain with the Sm…Sm distances of ca. 4.975 and 4.586<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>Å, respectively (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig2"></ce:float-anchor> and 
<ce:float-anchor refid="sch1"></ce:float-anchor>d). It is noteworthy that, up to date, the types of the chains formed by LN and isonicotinic acid that have been documented are mainly 1-1-1, 2-1-2, and 2-2-2 types (a–c, respectively). However, the 2-4-2 type is very rare. In <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, no <ce:italic>π</ce:italic>…<ce:italic>π</ce:italic> stacking interactions were established between the adjacent isonicotinic acid ligands. The one-dimensional polycationic chains, ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">2−</ce:sup> moieties, ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> anions, and the water molecules are linked by hydrogen bonds to yield a three-dimensional network (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>). It is proposed that O3W hydrogen bonds to its symmetry-related O3W′ to form a H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> moiety. Other crystallographic independent water molecules cannot form the H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> moiety, because they cannot hydrogen bond to their symmetry-related water molecules. The position of the proton between O3W and its symmetry-related O3W′ could not be structurally located due to the existence of the heavy samarium and zinc atoms. However, the existence of H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">+</ce:sup> has been confirmed by the ESI-MS spectra showing H<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>

Results and discussion

  presents relevant crystallographic and refinement data. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the structure of the title complex consists of [Sm(C6NO2H5)3(H2O)2]2 6+ cationic moieties, H5O2 + cations, ZnCl5 3- and ZnCl4 2- anions, and isolated water molecules, as shown in  . The Zn1 atom is tetrahedrally bounded by four chlorine atoms to form a ZnCl4 2- anion, while the Zn2 atom is coordinated by five chlorine atoms to form a ZnCl5 3- anion. In contrast to the numerous complexes containing ZnCl4 2- anion , no complex containing ZnCl5 3- anion was reported thus far, although one complex containing ZnCl6 4- anion has been reported . Therefore, it is first time to document ZnCl5 3- moieties. The bond lengths of Zn-Cl range from 2.152(1) to 2.442(1)Å with an average value of 2.273(2)Å, which are normal and comparable with the counterparts found in the literature . The Zn2 atom is positional disordered and the occupancy of Zn2 must be set to 0.5 to get rational structure model and thermal displacement parameters. The samarium atom is octahedrally coordinated by eight oxygen atoms, of which two are from two water molecules and six are from six isonicotinic acid ligands, yielding a distorted square anti-prism with the top and bottom planes defined by O(2)(1-x, y,     1   2    -z), O(1), O(5), O(6)(1-x, y,     1   2    -z), and O(2W), O(3), O(1W), and O(4)(    1   2    -x, -    1   2    -y, -z) atoms, respectively. The bond lengths of Sm-Oisonicotinic acid range from 2.363(2) to 2.424(2)Å with an average value of 2.395(2)Å, which is obviously shorter than that of Sm-Owater being of 2.469(2) and 2.526(2)Å, indicating that isonicotinic acid ligand has a stronger affinity to Sm3+ ion than that of water. The samarium atoms are alternately bridged by two or four μ 2-isonicotinic acid ligands in a 2-4-2 (the number indicates the number of the bridges) mode to construct a one-dimensional polycationic chain with the Sm…Sm distances of ca. 4.975 and 4.586Å, respectively (  and  d). It is noteworthy that, up to date, the types of the chains formed by LN and isonicotinic acid that have been documented are mainly 1-1-1, 2-1-2, and 2-2-2 types (a-c, respectively). However, the 2-4-2 type is very rare. In 1, no π…π stacking interactions were established between the adjacent isonicotinic acid ligands. The one-dimensional polycationic chains, ZnCl4 2- moieties, ZnCl5 3- anions, and the water molecules are linked by hydrogen bonds to yield a three-dimensional network ( ). It is proposed that O3W hydrogen bonds to its symmetry-related O3W' to form a H5O2 + moiety. Other crystallographic independent water molecules cannot form the H5O2 + moiety, because they cannot hydrogen bond to their symmetry-related water molecules. The position of the proton between O3W and its symmetry-related O3W' could not be structurally located due to the existence of the heavy samarium and zinc atoms. However, the existence of H5O2 + has been confirmed by the ESI-MS spectra showing H5O2 + at m/z=37.0211.

The solid-state excitation spectra of the title complex show that the effective energy absorption mainly takes place in the ultraviolet, violet, and blue regions in the range of 350–450<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm. The excitation bands of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possess three main peaks, 393, 410, and 421<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively. elements.clean_text: Taking into account the excellent luminescent property of Sm3+ ion, the luminescence of 1 was investigated at room temperature ( ). The solid-state excitation spectra of the title complex show that the effective energy absorption mainly takes place in the ultraviolet, violet, and blue regions in the range of 350-450nm. The excitation bands of complex 1 possess three main peaks, 393, 410, and 421nm, respectively. We further measured the corresponding emission spectra by selective excitation with the different excitation wavelengths of the title complex, and they show the similar emission position except for little distinction of luminescent intensities. Which indicates that all the excitation bands are effective. For complex 1, the emission spectra show three main and intense emission bands in blue and green regions with the maximum wavelengths of 460, 472, and 495nm upon photoexcitation at 393, 410, and 421nm, respectively. The changes of the emission spectra on the high-energy side on passing from an excitation wavelength of 393-421nm are significant. This is probably due to the fact that higher energy excitation wavelength can lead to stronger emission on the high-energy side, in other words, emission intensity on the high-energy side is more easily affected by excitation wavelength than that on the low-energy side. To understand the nature of the luminescence of 1, the luminescent spectra of pure isonicotinic acid were also measured under the same condition. For pure isonicotinic acid, the emission spectra show one intense emission band in blue region with the maximum wavelength of 455nm upon photoexcitation at 397nm ( ). The obvious discrepancy of the luminescent spectra of 1 and pure isonicotinic acid suggests that the emission spectra of 1 should not be assigned as an intraligand π-π* transition. To our knowledge, the characteristic emission bands of Sm3+ are around 561, 596, 643, and 701nm, which originate from 4 G 5/2→6 HJ  (J=    5   2    ,     7   2    ,     9   2    ,     11   2    ) of Sm3+ ions and, among them, the emission intensity of 4 G 5/2→6 H 7/2 (locates at about 596nm) is usually the strongest . For complex 1, most of these characteristic emission bands of Sm3+ cannot be found in , except for the small shoulder band of 596nm (4 G 5/2→6 H 7/2), indicating that in complex 1 all the characteristic emission bands of Sm3+ are very weak and maybe covered by the strong emission bands of 460, 472 and 495nm. Based on the above discussions, for complex 1, the three main emission bands of 460, 472 and 495nm should probably be assigned to the LMCT transition (charge transfer from isonicotinic acid ligand to samarium metal). Moreover, the existence of the ligand-based emissions in the luminescent spectra of 1 suggests that the isonicotinic acid ligand is not perfect enough for the sensitization of the Sm3+ ion. However, the existence of the small shoulder band of 596nm (4 G 5/2→6 H 7/2) of Sm3+ ion indicates that the intramolecular energy transfer process still exist between the triplet state of isonicotinic acid ligand to the resonant emissive energy level of Sm3+ ion, i.e. "antenna effect".

<ce:para view="all">To our knowledge, for most Sm<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> containing complexes they show obvious characteristic emission bands of Sm<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup>
 while in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> the characteristic emission bands of Sm<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> are very weak and not obvious. This discrepancy is probably attributed to the low energy transfer efficiency of the isonicotinic acid ligand in complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. It is proposed that the low energy transfer efficiency between the isonicotinic acid ligand and the Sm<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion is caused by the fact that the lowest triplet state energy level of the isonicotinic acid ligand does not match enough to the resonance level of Sm<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion.</ce:para>

<ce:section-title>Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para view="all">In brief, we have successfully prepared a metal–isonicotinic acid inorganic–organic hybrid complex via hydrothermal reaction. The crystal structure of the title complex is characteristic of a novel one-dimensional polycationic chain-like structure and unprecedented ZnCl<ce:inf loc="post">5</ce:inf>
<ce:sup loc="post">3−</ce:sup> species. The title complex shows intense luminescence in a wide region. Optical absorption spectra show that the title complex may be a candidate for potential photoelectric material. It is believed that more and more LN–IIB-based inorganic–organic hybrid complexes with good semiconductive and luminescent properties can be developed.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In brief, we have successfully prepared a metal-isonicotinic acid inorganic-organic hybrid complex via hydrothermal reaction. The crystal structure of the title complex is characteristic of a novel one-dimensional polycationic chain-like structure and unprecedented ZnCl5 3- species. The title complex shows intense luminescence in a wide region. Optical absorption spectra show that the title complex may be a candidate for potential photoelectric material. It is believed that more and more LN-IIB-based inorganic-organic hybrid complexes with good semiconductive and luminescent properties can be developed.

The title complex was prepared by mixing SmCl3⋅6H2O (1mmol, 0.365g), ZnCl2 (1mmol, 0.136g), isonicotinic acid (1mmol, 0.123g), and 10mL distilled water in a 25mL teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 180°C for 7 days. cln_elements.clean_text:
Abstract

A novel bimetallic 4f-3d metal-isonicotinic acid inorganic-organic hybrid complex [Sm(C6NO2H5)3(H2O)2]2  n ⋅(H5O2) n (ZnCl5) n (ZnCl4)2  n ⋅(H2O)2  n  (1) has been synthesized via hydrothermal reaction and structurally characterized by single-crystal X-ray diffraction. Complex 1 is characteristic of a one-dimensional polycationic chain-like structure and unprecedented ZnCl5 3- species. Photoluminescent investigation reveals that the title complex displays interesting emissions in a wide region. Optical absorption spectra of 1 reveal the presence of an optical gap of 3.59eV.

Results and discussion

  presents relevant crystallographic and refinement data. X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the structure of the title complex consists of [Sm(C6NO2H5)3(H2O)2]2 6+ cationic moieties, H5O2 + cations, ZnCl5 3- and ZnCl4 2- anions, and isolated water molecules, as shown in  . The Zn1 atom is tetrahedrally bounded by four chlorine atoms to form a ZnCl4 2- anion, while the Zn2 atom is coordinated by five chlorine atoms to form a ZnCl5 3- anion. In contrast to the numerous complexes containing ZnCl4 2- anion , no complex containing ZnCl5 3- anion was reported thus far, although one complex containing ZnCl6 4- anion has been reported . Therefore, it is first time to document ZnCl5 3- moieties. The bond lengths of Zn-Cl range from 2.152(1) to 2.442(1)Å with an average value of 2.273(2)Å, which are normal and comparable with the counterparts found in the literature . The Zn2 atom is positional disordered and the occupancy of Zn2 must be set to 0.5 to get rational structure model and thermal displacement parameters. The samarium atom is octahedrally coordinated by eight oxygen atoms, of which two are from two water molecules and six are from six isonicotinic acid ligands, yielding a distorted square anti-prism with the top and bottom planes defined by O(2)(1-x, y,     1   2    -z), O(1), O(5), O(6)(1-x, y,     1   2    -z), and O(2W), O(3), O(1W), and O(4)(    1   2    -x, -    1   2    -y, -z) atoms, respectively. The bond lengths of Sm-Oisonicotinic acid range from 2.363(2) to 2.424(2)Å with an average value of 2.395(2)Å, which is obviously shorter than that of Sm-Owater being of 2.469(2) and 2.526(2)Å, indicating that isonicotinic acid ligand has a stronger affinity to Sm3+ ion than that of water. The samarium atoms are alternately bridged by two or four μ 2-isonicotinic acid ligands in a 2-4-2 (the number indicates the number of the bridges) mode to construct a one-dimensional polycationic chain with the Sm…Sm distances of ca. 4.975 and 4.586Å, respectively (  and  d). It is noteworthy that, up to date, the types of the chains formed by LN and isonicotinic acid that have been documented are mainly 1-1-1, 2-1-2, and 2-2-2 types (a-c, respectively). However, the 2-4-2 type is very rare. In 1, no π…π stacking interactions were established between the adjacent isonicotinic acid ligands. The one-dimensional polycationic chains, ZnCl4 2- moieties, ZnCl5 3- anions, and the water molecules are linked by hydrogen bonds to yield a three-dimensional network ( ). It is proposed that O3W hydrogen bonds to its symmetry-related O3W' to form a H5O2 + moiety. Other crystallographic independent water molecules cannot form the H5O2 + moiety, because they cannot hydrogen bond to their symmetry-related water molecules. The position of the proton between O3W and its symmetry-related O3W' could not be structurally located due to the existence of the heavy samarium and zinc atoms. However, the existence of H5O2 + has been confirmed by the ESI-MS spectra showing H5O2 + at m/z=37.0211.

meta.name: bimetallic 4f–3d metal–isonicotinic acid inorganic–organic hybrid complex

<ce:para view="all">Taking into account the excellent luminescent property of Sm<ce:sup loc="post">3+</ce:sup> ion, the luminescence of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> was investigated at room temperature (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig4"></ce:float-anchor>). The solid-state excitation spectra of the title complex show that the effective energy absorption mainly takes place in the ultraviolet, violet, and blue regions in the range of 350–450<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm. The excitation bands of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> possess three main peaks, 393, 410, and 421<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively. We further measured the corresponding emission spectra by selective excitation with the different excitation wavelengths of the title complex, and they show the similar emission position except for little distinction of luminescent intensities. Which indicates that all the excitation bands are effective. For complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the emission spectra show three main and intense emission bands in blue and green regions with the maximum wavelengths of 460, 472, and 495<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm upon photoexcitation at 393, 410, and 421<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm, respectively. The changes of the emission spectra on the high-energy side on passing from an excitation wavelength of 393–421<ce:hsp sp="0.16"></ce:hsp>nm are significant. This is probably due to the fact that higher energy excitation wavelength can lead to stronger emission on the high-energy side, in other words, emission intensity on the high-energy side is more easily affected by excitation wavelength than that on the low-energy side. cln_elements.clean_text:
Taking into account the excellent luminescent property of Sm3+ ion, the luminescence of 1 was investigated at room temperature ( ). The solid-state excitation spectra of the title complex show that the effective energy absorption mainly takes place in the ultraviolet, violet, and blue regions in the range of 350-450nm. The excitation bands of complex 1 possess three main peaks, 393, 410, and 421nm, respectively. We further measured the corresponding emission spectra by selective excitation with the different excitation wavelengths of the title complex, and they show the similar emission position except for little distinction of luminescent intensities. Which indicates that all the excitation bands are effective. For complex 1, the emission spectra show three main and intense emission bands in blue and green regions with the maximum wavelengths of 460, 472, and 495nm upon photoexcitation at 393, 410, and 421nm, respectively. The changes of the emission spectra on the high-energy side on passing from an excitation wavelength of 393-421nm are significant. This is probably due to the fact that higher energy excitation wavelength can lead to stronger emission on the high-energy side, in other words, emission intensity on the high-energy side is more easily affected by excitation wavelength than that on the low-energy side. To understand the nature of the luminescence of 1, the luminescent spectra of pure isonicotinic acid were also measured under the same condition. For pure isonicotinic acid, the emission spectra show one intense emission band in blue region with the maximum wavelength of 455nm upon photoexcitation at 397nm ( ). The obvious discrepancy of the luminescent spectra of 1 and pure isonicotinic acid suggests that the emission spectra of 1 should not be assigned as an intraligand π-π* transition. To our knowledge, the characteristic emission bands of Sm3+ are around 561, 596, 643, and 701nm, which originate from 4 G 5/2→6 HJ  (J=    5   2    ,     7   2    ,     9   2    ,     11   2    ) of Sm3+ ions and, among them, the emission intensity of 4 G 5/2→6 H 7/2 (locates at about 596nm) is usually the strongest . For complex 1, most of these characteristic emission bands of Sm3+ cannot be found in , except for the small shoulder band of 596nm (4 G 5/2→6 H 7/2), indicating that in complex 1 all the characteristic emission bands of Sm3+ are very weak and maybe covered by the strong emission bands of 460, 472 and 495nm. Based on the above discussions, for complex 1, the three main emission bands of 460, 472 and 495nm should probably be assigned to the LMCT transition (charge transfer from isonicotinic acid ligand to samarium metal). Moreover, the existence of the ligand-based emissions in the luminescent spectra of 1 suggests that the isonicotinic acid ligand is not perfect enough for the sensitization of the Sm3+ ion. However, the existence of the small shoulder band of 596nm (4 G 5/2→6 H 7/2) of Sm3+ ion indicates that the intramolecular energy transfer process still exist between the triplet state of isonicotinic acid ligand to the resonant emissive energy level of Sm3+ ion, i.e. "antenna effect".

Optical absorption spectrum of 1 reveals the presence of an obviously optical gap of 3.59eV ( ), which suggests that complex 1 may be a potential wide-gap semiconductor and is consistent with the color of the crystal, as the cases found in the Ref. . The gradual slope of the optical absorption edge for 1 is indicative of the existence of indirect transitions . The optical absorption of 1 is likely originated from the charge-transfer excitations mainly from the p-like valence band of the chloride ligands to the 4s-like conduction band of the zinc center, similar to those reported in the Refs. .
